Professor Hinsley stated that
one way by which ties between
American and British universities could be strengthened would
be to exchange graduate students to a much greater degree.
"In England, our graduate students teach much more than do
those in the United States,
where the emphasis is so much
more upon research." He feels
that the two systems complement each other, and that there
is a need for both types in the
academic world.

Students desiring a position
as life-guard at the new pool,
please contact Coach William
Klamer in the athletic center.
The position is salaried, and
students will be permitted to
work a maximum of ten hours
per week. Senior life-saving
certification is required.

and give a full-page fold-out
to his image.

PHOTO-EXHIBIT
The Johns Hopkins Film
Guild-Camera Club is sponsoring an exhibit of student photographs in its exhibit cabinets
near the old library. Anyone interested in entering photographs
(undergrad. or grad.) should
send them to Carl Davis, box
2087, or Kirk Gardner, box 466,
by Wednesday of next week. The
dry-mounting will be done free
by the Film-Club.

In substance anti general appearance, the Barnstormers can claim a major advance. There can aptly be
observed a renaissance for the dramatic group at Hopkins, for one of the most productive and popular organizations, experienced a step-down from excellence this
past year. The previous season was a period of poor
leadership, of political agony and of some undramatic
productions.

The new spirit is evidenced in the two productions
to be given this weekend and next week; both worthy of
the most enthusiastic student support."The Fantasticks"
is in our memory the first time the Barnstormers have
attempted a musical, and from indications of practices
held in the barn, the production will be a success musigaily and dramatically.

Movement Dominates Show
Seniors Matthew Robbins and
Walter Murch are responsible
for the current exhibition of
paintings, drawings and sculpture in the Sherwood Room of
Levering Hall. This, their first
one-man (two man) show in
Baltimore is a fair sampling of
their unusual collaborative talents which have produced a
number of memorable works.
They are evidently interested
in motorcycles since one-third
of the show consists of large ink-

wash drawings of motorcycle
racers in action. Beyond a competent level of draftsmanship
these pictures treat the men and
machines as a unit, in isolation
on the page. The result is a flattening of the form and an emphasis on outline.
By choosing to eliminate all
pictorial detail save that which
appears on the bikes and riders
the background field remains
intentionally neutral. Thus, in
spite of the high degree of action and drama engendered by

as commissioned, they will be

Barnstormers Open 'Parable On Romance' Wed.
The Fantasticks, "a parable about

romance," will be re-created by the
Barnstormers at the Barn next Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday evenings,
with a special performance at Goucher
Saturday night, matinees on Saturday
and Sunday at the Barn, and a performance at the Barn on Sunday evening.
Evening shows are 8:30, matinees at
2:30. Tickets, which are free, and are
required, owing to the limited seating
In the Barn, may be reserved by calling

either 243-7581 or 243-7582, or through
the Office of Special Events, Shriver
Hall; 467-3000, ext. 704.

The Fan tasticks, by Tom Jones and
Harvey Schmidt, has been running off
Broadway in New York since May of
1959, thus making it the longest running show in New York. The musical'
s
success has spread around the world,
and it was recently presented on
national television.
The appeal of the play, using only
eight characters and a piano, is based

BECKERS
31st and GREENMOUNT AVE

upon the unique sense of participation
by the audience. This is not a physical
participation, rather it is a process
of the imagination. The audience is invited, from the beginning "to follow"
Into the spirit of the play, a spirit
which is at once whimsical as it is simply profound.

from its humble beginnings, to its
noble
climax. For, while we all may
wish
to constantly remain in the "forest,
where woodchucks woo. and leaves wax
green, and vines entwine like lovers. . ."
and to remain forever in the moonlight
"despite what pretty poets say, the
night is only half the day."

Suggested by the play of Edmond
Rostand, Les Romanesques, The Fantasticks is the story of "a boy, a girl,
two fathers, and a wall." The search
for love is traced throughout the play,

The play invites one to realize. that
"deep in December it's nice to remember, without a hurt. the heart is hollow
... deep in December, it's nice to remember, and follow ... ."

Hopkins has gone 'through the first half of its lacrosse
season playing oaeh game on the same level as its opponent—
looking good against good opposition and bad against bad
trams.
Question for the second half of the season: Is Hopkins
good enough to play on the level of Army and Navy!
Tomorrow the Jays. will have to prove themselves against
the former, and the test will be whether or not Bob Scott's
crew can pin down the Cadets' attack while it struggles to
get its own attack moving.
I doubt that Army has yet faced a defensive unit as strong
as Hopkins' this year, except for Alt. Washington; hut offense
is the question mark for Ilopkim.

injuries tomorrow—if they play. Pfeifer is easily the Jays'
top offensive threat. He has more fitness than any man on
the team, but he'll need speed to keep that lutlf-step lead on
a defenseman. A sore leg won't help.

Full House
In substance anti general appearance, the Barnstormers can claim a major advance. There can aptly be
observed a renaissance for the dramatic group at Hopkins, for one of the most productive and popular organizations, experienced a step-down from excellence this
past year. The previous season was a period of poor
leadership, of political agony and of some undramatic
productions.

The new spirit is evidenced in the two productions
to be given this weekend and next week; both worthy of
the most enthusiastic student support."The Fantasticks"
is in our memory the first time the Barnstormers have
attempted a musical, and from indications of practices
held in the barn, the production will be a success musigaily and dramatically.

Movement Dominates Show
Seniors Matthew Robbins and
Walter Murch are responsible
for the current exhibition of
paintings, drawings and sculpture in the Sherwood Room of
Levering Hall. This, their first
one-man (two man) show in
Baltimore is a fair sampling of
their unusual collaborative talents which have produced a
number of memorable works.
They are evidently interested
in motorcycles since one-third
of the show consists of large ink-

wash drawings of motorcycle
racers in action. Beyond a competent level of draftsmanship
these pictures treat the men and
machines as a unit, in isolation
on the page. The result is a flattening of the form and an emphasis on outline.
By choosing to eliminate all
pictorial detail save that which
appears on the bikes and riders
the background field remains
intentionally neutral. Thus, in
spite of the high degree of action and drama engendered by

Barnstormers Open 'Parable On Romance' Wed.
The Fantasticks, "a parable about

romance," will be re-created by the
Barnstormers at the Barn next Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday evenings,
with a special performance at Goucher
Saturday night, matinees on Saturday
and Sunday at the Barn, and a performance at the Barn on Sunday evening.
Evening shows are 8:30, matinees at
2:30. Tickets, which are free, and are
required, owing to the limited seating
In the Barn, may be reserved by calling

either 243-7581 or 243-7582, or through
the Office of Special Events, Shriver
Hall; 467-3000, ext. 704.

The Fan tasticks, by Tom Jones and
Harvey Schmidt, has been running off
Broadway in New York since May of
1959, thus making it the longest running show in New York. The musical'
s
success has spread around the world,
and it was recently presented on
national television.
The appeal of the play, using only
eight characters and a piano, is based

BECKERS
31st and GREENMOUNT AVE

upon the unique sense of participation
by the audience. This is not a physical
participation, rather it is a process
of the imagination. The audience is invited, from the beginning "to follow"
Into the spirit of the play, a spirit
which is at once whimsical as it is simply profound.

from its humble beginnings, to its
noble
climax. For, while we all may
wish
to constantly remain in the "forest,
where woodchucks woo. and leaves wax
green, and vines entwine like lovers. . ."
and to remain forever in the moonlight
"despite what pretty poets say, the
night is only half the day."

Suggested by the play of Edmond
Rostand, Les Romanesques, The Fantasticks is the story of "a boy, a girl,
two fathers, and a wall." The search
for love is traced throughout the play,

The play invites one to realize. that
"deep in December it's nice to remember, without a hurt. the heart is hollow
... deep in December, it's nice to remember, and follow ... ."

Stanley Sick
To further dim his squad's
outlook, Coach Gary Barrette
was greeted last Saturday with
the news that starting shortstop Dick Stanley was sick and
probably out for the year, which
necessitated a sudden infield
change for the Swarthmore
game. Earlier in the week, reserve shortstop Mike Glasgow
dropped off the squad, leaving
the varsity mentor with a considerable hole to fill at that position.

The current infield situation
has either Otis Huston or Bill
Sargent at first base, Jerry
Moore and Ken Flowers at second or third, Len Linton and
Huston sharing the third base
spot when no one else is there,
and ex-first baseman Roger Seafoss playing short. Barrette plans
plenty of platooning in hopes
of beefing up the attack.

Hopkins has gone 'through the first half of its lacrosse
season playing oaeh game on the same level as its opponent—
looking good against good opposition and bad against bad
trams.
Question for the second half of the season: Is Hopkins
good enough to play on the level of Army and Navy!
Tomorrow the Jays. will have to prove themselves against
the former, and the test will be whether or not Bob Scott's
crew can pin down the Cadets' attack while it struggles to
get its own attack moving.
I doubt that Army has yet faced a defensive unit as strong
as Hopkins' this year, except for Alt. Washington; hut offense
is the question mark for Ilopkim.
Both Jerry Pfeifer and Ray Gordon will be ploying with
injuries tomorrow—if they play. Pfeifer is easily the Jays'
top offensive threat. He has more fitness than any man on
the team, but he'll need speed to keep that lutlf-step lead on
a defenseman. A sore leg won't help.
